review_title: Not an easy place to work at - but you learn to love it
pros: Great job to be exposed to a faster paced industry, the people I personally worked with were all such awesome people so I enjoyed coming to work everyday for the most part. Also, the perks that come with being a barista in regards to free coffee is quite literally one of the best, as it has been a true dream of mine previously for years (who wouldnt feel the same?) to not have to spend so much money on my coffee everyday. Saving money and making money simultaneously was pretty cool. I built many really cool friendships with customers too. The training was actually really thorough and I was able to do the job correctly rather quickly.I really did enjoy my time there. If I could go back to work it part time again, I think I would.
cons: Can be really... really... and I mean really stressful. Especially working on bar during happy hour in NYC. In the summertime. The ticketline would be down to the floor and wrapped around our ankles. That is in no way an exaggeration. Not to be offensive, but at the end of a shift sometimes it really almost felt like coming out of a war zone (that is exaggerated, but you get the picture). It certainly builds character. I would sit on the bus on my way home not believing how I even got out of there. Scheduling can be a bit unfair too sometimes when it comes to who got the most hours.

review_title: Love it, would do it again in a heartbeat

pros:
-Great connections with co-workers, manager, and customers. 
-Being able to have a say in the day-to-day of the store.
-Bit of extra pay.
-You are more likely to be asked to train new baristas.
-College and stock opportunities
cons:
-Not enough pay for the additional responsibility. (Although, I think wages have risen since I've worked there.) 
-Customers and co-workers look to you with all concerns in the absence of the manager, which may become overwhelming, and most times, you would be the only lead in the store. 
-Closing is much harder if your baristas are slow or uncooperative, on top of the additional tasks that need to be done such as counting money and inventory, leaving you responsible for a late close. 
-This isn't necessarily bad, but you must set aside an hour each week for meetings. This gives you and the other team leads a chance to look over updates within the company and talk about any concerns.

pros: If you are fluent in Starbucks' particular brand of corporate motivational mumbo-jumbo, and willing to play pretend, the job can be cushy and rewarding by you not doing anything useful as a leader but being able to pat yourself on the back for covering the right buzzwords. Many internal promotes for district manager have only mastered the jargon and corporate philosophy, but ran crappy ineffectual stores as store managers and now will proceed leading the blind.
cons:
Fast Food: Imagine Mcdonald's volume but with no set system or structure for the company. Managers are supposed to innovate and tailor set-ups for "their store" which amounts to structural chaos across the company. Essentially, Starbucks turned fast food with mobile order and drive through models becoming dominant, but had no infrastructure or changes to set up to actually support that huge change in business. Why do you think employees are unionizing across the company

Technology: Atrocious technology for years. They rolled out automated ordering for stores this fall and it took months for the damage to slow down. Stores across the country were getting double the inventory they could fit every day for weeks, or nothing at all. They instructed the teams to trust the system and it would catch up when the impact in stores was disastrous. That's just one example of their incessant poor innovation. 

Cultish: this doesn't get said enough about the company. There is a massive groupthink problem among store managers. You are sort of indoctrinated by lots of what amounts to company propaganda to always have faith in their demonstrably crappy systems and initiatives which are always misguided if not straight-up detrimental. No one provides actual feedback to district managers because they've learned it's not what we do. As I mentioned, many DMs are not hyper competent managers who can lead and teach others, but people who can speak to the corporate philosophy and logic.

Disorganized: the Starbucks homepage is unsearchable and has lots of redundant links and navigation

Overcomplicated: Store managers are given useless data dumps, busy work and meetings that prevent them from actually being useful in their stores. They have a foot in corporate and a foot in store operations and NEWSFLASH! it's coffees, teas and frozen food warmed up, NOT super complicated. But it has to be overly complicated at Starbucks.

pros:
-I enjoyed the free drinks, very flexible schedule and met some amazing coworkers while on the job.
-Starbucks provides its employees with free online schooling (only if the employee wishes to attend). 
-Starbucks gives its employees free stocks (but only every two years).
cons:
-Very low pay. There is definitely no way to live on this kind of salary, even if you work full time (at least in NYC).
-You meet some of the most entitled, immature customers. There are customers that will literally scream at you for their OWN MISTAKES (such as ordering the wrong drink).
-For some reason, there is ALWAYS workplace drama between coworkers. It became unbearable at times.
-Prepare to have a handful of lazy coworkers that aren't held accountable for their actions. I've worked with some lazy people that should have gotten fired for being incompetent. 
-Depending on how busy your Starbucks store is, prepare to be physically and mentally drained by the end of your shift.
-Bad experiences with the district manager. Starbucks corporate feels really disconnected from reality and has unrealistic expectations.

cons: There is no empathy in a Starbucks environment, especially for new people, which is why this job has such a high turnover. As a "partner" of three years, and having worked at 4 different locations, nobody cares about helping other people and making yourself available or giving them every moment outside of school is not going to be rewarded with loyalty or even hours when your schedule opens up. pros: The people you work with can be great friends. Starbucks has always had a great atmosphere to work in and the benefits are actually quite good.

review_title: Let customers walk all over you
pros:
- There are free food and drink benefits for employees, though they're limited.
- Schedule flexibility.
- Easy ability to swap shifts or get shifts covered.
cons:
- The customers are extremely entitled and the culture of the business only encourages it. They will yell and scream at you and do anything they can to scam you out of a free drink, and you are expected to allow them to.
- Never enough people scheduled to cover shifts. You will be taking orders on drive thru, handling payment at the window and handing them their food and drinks, while also going around to help make the food and drinks.
- Drive thru times are constantly hounded as the most important metric despite there not being enough people scheduled to reasonably bring them down. You are expected to have customers in and out in under a minute, even when they are allowed to order 5+ drinks at once.

review_title: It's okay if you don't have anywhere better to work.
pros: Free food and drinks, fellow employees tend to not be transphobic.
cons: Pay is terrible for the sheer number of skills you need and how much work you do. It wouldn't be as bad if you could reliably get 30 or more hours, but management will over hire and then cut hours with no warning so their many employees only get 10-20 hours each. It can take up to 8 months to be skilled enough to work in all areas of the store without problems. Management will get onto you if you stand still for even a few seconds. Rarely if ever will they schedule more than the bare minimum of employees for the store to function, not taking into account anticipated rush hours or increased business depending on the season. If you're trans you can get a badge with your pronouns but nothing will be done if customers are homophobic.

pros: Nice Perks, friendly staff, flexible hours, opportunity to acquire stock, more breaks compared to other retail/food service jobs, some wage raises, good health benefits
cons: Customer demand can get really stressful, difficult to find last minute coverage for shifts, big learning curve when it comes to making drinks, health benefits are conditional on how often you work for them, it's about a 20hr week minimum to qualify, risk of repetitive injuries/strains when working long shifts, lack of discipline for some staff. In the past I've had some coworkers who were really rude or unpleasant to be around, and the company really hesitated to confront these issues, Ive heard of baristas being switched to other locations when they shouldve been fired, and managers getting preferential treatment. Overall if you have nice coworkers and good management, it's a positive place to work, but if not I'd recommend switching locations or work somewhere else

cons: the managers i’ve had are wonderful but the people who are really in charge are so out of touch and they really don’t care. things have changed so much since the pandemic. but the absolute worst part is the labor. it feels like you’re constantly running around trying to do the job of 4 people because there may only be two of you working for periods of time, even when it’s busy. when you become a shift the responsibilities really start to get out of hand. you’re basically expected to do the job of the store manager. your on call constantly, come in early, stay late to clean up the mess. open at 4am one day close at 11 pm the next. shifts can easily end up getting burnt out. there’s a lot of pressure that can come with it.

review_title: Fun Job But Super Fast Paced
pros: Overall job is really fun, especially when customers trust you enough to recommend them a drink they would love. My managers and co-workers are super nice and understanding and easy to get along with. Not a lot of drama going on because we're too busy to stand around and gossip. Good benefits such as health, dental, and vision insurance and free therapy sessions. Tip outs are done weekly at my location based on amount of hours worked. There is also no real attendance policy as starbucks seems to understand that people get sick or emergency situations happen. Starbucks also hires within if you're wanting to move up.
cons: Training is super quick and not very in depth. You're also not allowed to really work on the floor during peak when you're new even though I think thats the best way to learn (could also just be my location's "rule"). The pay is mediocre for the amount of stress that you go through as it's a very busy store all times of the day, and the streaming Karen's don't make it any better.

review_title: The only benefits are the benefits
pros: Have fun talking to people, making friends with co-workers and regulars. I also got a paid covid leave, paid medical leave when I needed surgery, the pay for shift supervisors isn't terrible, diverse culture, usually with cool and fun people. They also have discounts for Starbucks employees at places like sketchers, some gyms, and on vacations, and even electronics and home appliances.
cons: My store manager was MIA most of the time, had no idea how to be a barista, run a shift, and could not close the store by herself. She took no ownership of the employee's performance and continued to force us to be understaffed until a DM told her to get more staffing. At the end of the day, they'll tell you you need to get better line times to have your store improve, failing to see that you need more staff in order for the store to improve. They are doing a good job providing benefits but a poor job seeing how stores are being run.

cons: The position can be a little monotonous at times, however definitely made more enjoyable by customers and colleagues. Management can vary, I’ve experienced awesome managers as well as some that are completely disorganized and checked/out.

pros:
- Meeting and forming wholesome relationships with regulars (seeing them in line can truly make a terrible shift a little better)
- Making drinks! While obvious, this is a pro for those people who maybe want to be a bartender or remain a barista in the future! It gets you used to the fast paced environment you're bound to work in at any barista job, and it's actually really fun once you get the hang of it!
- Forming long lasting friendships with your coworkers. Some of the people I met at Starbucks are still incredibly important in my life even after I left; working with people who make you laugh and help you when you're down is really important at a stressful job such as this one
- Clean Plays! Every month or so, your store will have a night where a few workers will stay after the store has closed and do a deep clean of the store. Count yourself lucky if you get to be involved; it's like getting paid to have fun and clean with your coworkers without having to worry about a line of people outside
- Free drinks! You usually can get free drinks during your shifts, AND a free food item for your lunch
- Breaks. For an 8 or 7 hour shift, you get two paid 10 minute breaks and 1 unpaid 30 minute break
cons:
- Consistently un-clean environment. Due to the large amount of liquids used behind the bar throughout the day, the floors (even if there are mats) are absolutely soaked. Even if you have completely nonslip shoes, you are bound to slip. In addition to such, the counters get messy very rapidly and become impossible to clean during most days from 9am-5pm due to the consistent rush of customers which not only makes it incredibly difficult to work, it also starts to smell and is generally very gross.
- VERY rude customers. You should expect the rudest of the rude at Starbucks. People are not going there thinking "I'm gonna get a quick drink or two and be on my way", they are thinking "I am here for my coffee fast because this is a large coffee chain MEANT for quick coffee". As a result, customers tend to become completely infuriated when the line takes longer than 10 minutes because they are expecting consistently quick service; what they don't realize is everyone else in line is expecting the same, and due to the popularity of the company there are always lots of customers in line, and theres only so fast your team can produce food and drinks. I've had countless nightmarish experiences with unpleasant customers, but again having fun coworkers makes all the difference. If someone screams at you, you can fall back on your fellow coworkers to lift you back up.
- Constant rush. As I explained in the previous bullet, pretty much every day (but especially on weekends) there is a consistent rush from roughly 8 or 9am to about 5pm. During this time, if you're on bar, you better PRAY you're paired with someone else who can bust out drinks fast; if not, you're going to have lots of angry customers and the situation will become extremely overwhelming VERY quickly
- Company Policies not Upheld. This may not be at every Starbucks, but at the one I worked at many of the company policies we all learned about at the start of our jobs were not upheld at all. I had been put down by my manager one time for calling out with a headache so severe I couldn't see three feet ahead of me, and this happened to most of my other coworkers as well. Sexual harassment allegations were disturbingly high; it became a big problem because lots of the harassment of myself and my coworkers came from a higher up such as a shift manager, so we would be afraid to say anything for fear of either losing our jobs, getting our hours cut, or said harasser giving us positions at work we didn't like just to spite us. Again, I'm sure this isn't every Starbucks, but i have heard from more than one Starbucks other than mine that had similar things go on.

If you want to climb the ladder, you will need to only say yes to everything any manager ever says to you, never complain.
Finally, the anti-union stance Starbucks is taking contradicts their constant effort to convince the public how progressive they are.

Bandanas and scarves were frowned upon as well, so I had to plan my hairstyles in advance. I heard they plan to offer more inclusive hair coverings, but I am not sure when they will be released.

pros:
I considered my coworkers my family because we went through everything together. Management did a great job hiring some of the best people I’ve ever known.

The benefits are pretty great since you can get them working part time.
cons:
The biggest problem I had was never getting promoted after working 2 years and training almost every new hire while being in college and working a second job. My manager was terrible with communication and told me I couldn’t get promoted if I didn’t have open availability?

I worked the busiest store in the region and often felt like my team was never recognized, only told to keep improving. Tips were never great and management always stood by the customer is always right. 

Been yelled at, harassed and discriminated by customers but was always told, if they keep buying, we will service them.

Turnover rate is huge so don’t expect working with the same team for a long time at a busy location. The burnout is real and it’s a lot of work behind the counter.

review_title: decent pay but horrible experience overall
pros:
-perks: free food, drinks, coffee weekly
-partners mostly enjoyable to be around

cons:
-customers were the worst, not all, but more than enough
-mobile ordering/uber eats orders ruined the experience for customers & employees
-management took advantage of "part-time" & 3 week out scheduling after being hired to just schedule right under 40 hrs AND would often ask you to work more shifts on days off 
-stressful environment & I know what you're thinking.. its just coffee? How hard can it be? Wait times became 20-40 minutes, customers became upset easily & we'd end up throwing out drinks due to the system in place for processing order while overworking & not taking breaks. It's a physically draining job, if you're not actually on bar, you're cleaning, dealing with customers, re-stocking, etc. 
-tiktok influencing people to add so many extra modifications made the job harder; it seems like adding a few modifications isn't an issue since that is our job to make the drinks. However, the problem was not with customers or partners, but the way that starbucks expects us to make a drink within 48 seconds despite all the extra modifications which take time. We simply do not have enough time to make them perfectly especially when 2-3 people call out in a day. It's unfortunate for customers and employees
** this is a somewhat biased review due to store being understaffed

review_title: Not The Greatest but Not The Worst
pros: Depending on how you pick up new things, it's really easy to learn how to make their products, operate machines, know how the store is run, and create a good customer experience. One really good pro you can get from working at Starbucks is building communication skills, gaining food and drink preparation experience, and obtaining good leadership skills.
cons: Based on personal experiences, there have been instances where the job will get overwhelming. By overwhelming, I mean that it can be a job where it can be difficult to juggle many tasks at one time. From not only making drinks, fixing a problem, and communicate to the best of our abilities, and having co-workers who either don't want to work with you or make the shift a nightmare. Personal experience-wise, some (not all) people who I have worked with can be very rude with not only how they talk to you but how they show their actions. Company-wise, I can say that Starbucks is a company that is solely based on customer connections and making the moment right every time even if it means getting yelled at by customers or treated like a dog by them. I have been cursed out many times by customers when I try to make the moment right and it always blows up in my face. Starbucks gives customers the upper hand even if they are right or wrong in the situation and the employees can get bad repercussions from it. Overall, Starbucks can have its good and bad moments just like any job.
